Comment: I mean, my education about American history has always highlighted the victories when the public at large was able to rein in the power of elites. The Revolution itself, the end of slavery, reforms for workers rights after the Gilded Age.  A democracy shouldn't have billionaires. Sure, all economic activity has some element of coercion to it, but nobody does labor to earn a billion dollars; nobody lives long enough for that. You only get to billions by claiming a share of the wealth a bunch of other people produce.  If you can see that feudalism was wrong, and that slavery was wrong, and that child labor and company stores were wrong, and that sweat shops are wrong, I don't think it should be a big leap to see that, even if it's less viscerally dangerous, to extract a bit of wealth from millions of people is also extremely coercive. It's exploitation.
